greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Array read by antidiagonals of a(n) = a(n-1)*k-((k-1)/(k^n)) where a(0)=1 and k=(sqrt(x^2+1)+x)^2 for integers x>=1.
comment: Conjecture: Given function f(x, y)=(sqrt(x^2+y)+x)^2; constant k=f(x, y); and initial term a(0)=1; then for all integers x>=1 and y=[+-]1, k may be irrational, but sequence a(n)=a(n-1)*k-((k-1)/(k^n)) always produces integer sequences; y=1 results shown here; y=-1 results are A188646.

Also square array A(n,k), n >= 1, k >= 0, read by antidiagonals, where A(n,k) is (1/sqrt(n^2+1)) * T_{2*k+1}(sqrt(n^2+1)), with T the Chebyshev polynomial of the first kind. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Jan 02 2019
link: Index entries for sequences related to Chebyshev polynomials.
xref: Row 1 is A001653, row 2 is A007805, row 3 is A097315, row 4 is A078988, row 5 is A097727, row 6 is A097730, row 7 is A097733, row 8 is A097736, row 9 is A097739, row 10 is A097742, row 11 is A097767, row 12 is A097770, row 13 is A097773.
Cf. A188645, A188646 (f(x, y) as above with y=-1).
results.author: _Charles L. Hohn_, Apr 06 2011
ext: Edited and extended by _Seiichi Manyama_, Jan 02 2019
